Expectation1: Coordinate with other air traffic controllers to ensure smooth traffic flow
Situation1: Thunderstorm cells force multiple flights to reroute, increasing handoffs between sectors.
Expectation2: Arrive on time for scheduled volunteer shifts
Situation2: They are the only volunteer assigned to unlock the facility and begin the service for people already waiting outside.
Story: The radar screen flickered with a dozen rerouted flights, each one a blinking demand for my attention. My headset buzzed with voices—colleagues coordinating handoffs, pilots requesting vectors around the thunderstorm cells. I felt the weight of every decision, knowing a single misstep could ripple through the entire airspace. My shift was supposed to end in ten minutes, but the storm had thrown everything into chaos. I glanced at my phone: a reminder for my volunteer shift. I was the only one scheduled to unlock the facility, and people would already be waiting outside, counting on me to start the service. The expectation was clear—be there on time, open the doors, offer help. But here, in the tower, my team needed me just as much. I could feel the tension knotting in my chest, torn between the urgent needs of the skies and the waiting faces at the facility. The clock ticked forward, and I wrestled with the impossible choice, knowing I couldn’t be in two places at once.
